plausible_answers.text: The nature and definition of matter

qas.question: What is the opposite of hylomorphism?
What is the opposite of atomism?
What is the term for zero kinds of matter?
What is the term for lacking then gaining properties?

context: <b1_0>The nature and definition of <a0_0>matter<b1_0/><a0_0/> - like other key concepts in science and philosophy - have occasioned much debate. Is there a single kind of matter (<b3_0><b4_0>hyle<b4_0/><b3_0/>) which everything is made of, or multiple kinds? Is matter a continuous substance capable of expressing multiple forms (hylomorphism), or a number of discrete, unchanging constituents (<b2_0>atomism<b2_0/>)? Does it have intrinsic properties (substance theory), or is it lacking them (<b5_0>prima materia<b5_0/>)?
